actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on November 7, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. LaMalfa moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House resumed with one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the National Emergency With Respect to the Threat From Securities Investments That Finance Certain Companies of the People's Republic of China is to continue in effect beyond November 12, 2023.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-78).

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk transmitted to the House a sealed envelope received from the White House on November 3, 2023, at 3:20 p.m., said to contain a message from the President regarding the Continuation of the National Emergency With Respect to the Threat From Securities Investments That Finance Certain Companies of the People's Republic of China.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification that the Department of State and the Department of the Interior have been directed to report on the outcome of the ongoing negotiations at the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) Standing Committee meeting in Geneva on November 6-10, 2023 regarding the taking of eight species of pangolin by nationals of the People's Republic of China.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committees on Foreign Affairs and Natural Resources and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-77).

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk transmitted to the House a sealed envelope received from the White House on November 3, 2023, at 3:20 p.m., said to contain a message from the President regarding the President's notification to the Congress consistent with section 8 of the Fishermen's Protective Act of 1967, as amended (22 U.S.C. 1978).
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 4820 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Cole moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Brecheen amendment No. 30, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Brecheen amendment No. 30.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Brecheen,  numbered 30 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce funding for the Office of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity to FY19 levels.

At the conclusion of debate on the Grothman amendment No. 29, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Grothman amendment No. 29.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Grothman,  numbered 29 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decrease funding for the Office of the Chief Human Capital Officer at the Department of Housing and Urban Development to express concern regarding the Diversity Council and the associated race, ethnicity, gender, and sexual orientation-based Affinity or Employee Resource Groups.

At the conclusion of debate on the Perry amendment No. 25, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Perry demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 25.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 25 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to eliminate funding for grants to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 24.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 24 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decrease funding for grants to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority to emphasize the importance of restoring public safety on the DC Metro.
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Failed by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 23.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 23 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to eliminate funding for Capital Investment Grants.
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Failed by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 22.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 22 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce Transit Infrastructure Grant funding to $0.

At the conclusion of debate on the Perry amendment No. 20, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 20.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 20 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to strike National Network Grants.
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 6.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 6 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to restore funding for the National Surface Transportation and Innovation Finance Bureau to FY22 funding levels.

At the conclusion of debate on the Escobar amendment No. 5, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Escobar demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Escobar amendment No. 5.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Escobar,  numbered 5 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decrease the National Surface Transportation and Innovative Finance Bureau in recognition of the DOT Thriving Communities Program.
On agreeing to the Lawler amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Lawler amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Lawler,  numbered 3 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase the Consolidated Rail Infrastructure and Safety Improvements program (CRISI) account by $10 million to support rail safety with an equal offset to the Office of the Secretary of Transportation.
On agreeing to the Cole amendments; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 20 minutes of debate on the Cole amendment en bloc.

Amendments en bloc  offered by Mr. Cole,  comprised of the following amendments printed in Part B of House Report 117-261 as en bloc: Nos. 1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21, 26, 27, 28, 33, 35, 38, 39, 41, and 42.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4820 — "Making appropriations for the Departments of Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
On approving the Journal Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 359
actions-list.actionItem: 24 (Roll no. 600).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 359 — "To establish Fort San Gerónimo del Boquerón in Puerto Rico as an affiliated area of the National Park System, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 384
actions-list.actionItem: 1 (Roll no. 599).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1607 — "To clarify jurisdiction with respect to certain Bureau of Reclamation pumped storage development, and for other purposes."

The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on the motions to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 1607, as amended, H.R. 359, and agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal, if ordered, on which further proceedings had been postponed.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Ms. Jacobs notified the House of her intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 6.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 4820 as unfinished business.
On motion that the Committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Cole moved that the Committee rise.
The Committee of the Whole resumed with debate on H.R. 4820.
Subsequently, the Committee of the Whole resumed its sitting.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed S. 447, S. 499, S. 656, S. 1648, S. 1973, S. 3222, H.R. 1226, and H.R. 4366 amended. Senate agreed to S. Con. Res. 7.
The Committee of the Whole rose informally to receive a message from the Senate.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 4820.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Don Bacon to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 838 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4821, H.R. 4820 and H.R. 6126. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4821 and H.R. 4820 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate for each bill. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 6126, under a closed rule, with one hour of general debate. Each measure has one motion to recommit.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 838. H.R. 4820 — "Making appropriations for the Departments of Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 6.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1318.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1318 — "To authorize the location of a monument on the National Mall to commemorate and honor the women's suffrage movement and the passage of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Mr. Westerman objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2717.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 2717 — "To authorize the National Medal of Honor Museum Foundation to establish a commemorative work on the National Mall to honor the extraordinary acts of valor, selfless service, and sacrifice displayed by Medal of Honor recipients."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 359.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 359 — "To establish Fort San Gerónimo del Boquerón in Puerto Rico as an affiliated area of the National Park System, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3448.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3448 — "To amend chapter 3081 of title 54, United States Code, to enhance the protection and preservation of America's battlefields."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Mr. Westerman objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1722.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1722 — "To amend the Grand Ronde Reservation Act, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1607.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1607 — "To clarify jurisdiction with respect to certain Bureau of Reclamation pumped storage development, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 6.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to 44 U.S.C. 2702, the Acting Clerk notified the House that he had hereby reappointed as a member of the Advisory Committee on the Records of Congress the following person: Ms. Danna Bell, Washington, D.C.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Ms. Greene (GA) notified the House of her intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. McCormick notified the House of his intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.
The Chair designated Mrs. Houchin to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.

The Chair announced that he had examined the Journal of the last day's proceedings and had approved it. Mrs. Houchin demanded that the question be put on agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal and by voice vote, the Chair announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mrs. Houchin objected to the voice vote based upon the absence of a quorum and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal until a time to be announced.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 6.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Adrian Smith to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
